title: Can you write a song without a song structure? - Quora

response.answer_text: You can, but people wouldn't like or buy it. It would be like buying a book that's just one long run on sentence that doesn't really have a point and just rambles on. Structure allows a hook (lyrically, or melodically) to stand out. Without structure, the song wouldn't have any direction. It would be hard to perform live. It would be hard to listen to. There's nothing there to focus your attention.

Absolutely. It’s not advisable if you want an audience, but it’s doable. Prog and/or jazz is notorious (note-orious hurhur) for throwing song structure out the window. Personally, I love those genres bc I’m obsessed with polyrhythms and “wtf this chord progression sounds good and theory says it shouldn’t” but I’m also the only person I know who’s into that Pop music is 3 chords played for a thousand ppl. Jazz/Prog is a thousand chords played for 3 ppl

most song lyrics seem like they’re just memos or letters squished into some melody. so, lyric doesn’t need a form. and, melody is anything you call a song — forty minutes of a jack-hammer drilling can be a song if you want.
